reviews.review_msg: Awwww how can anyone not like Habib? he is like a teddy bear with an awesome personality! :P He is also an amazing prof and he certainly knows his stuff and has a passion for what he does! Because of him, I have decided to obtain a minor in gero
decent course. Not too difficult to get a good grade.  Ask him many questions about the mt or final for more hints
I loved this course. Relatively easy for an upper division course and Habib was great.
Hi lectures were all over the place. Not informative at all, just covered the main concepts basically. Thank god for his TA. If possible, avoid. However, he is kind and approachable.

I disagree with the ratings mentioned by others. Sarah is excited about gerontology and always available when I've reached out for extra help. She does expect students to attend class and participate but is engaged with those students who engage with her. She provided more feedback on my work than any other professor ever has, so I know she cares.

Do not take this class people. This prof has given me the worst possible experience at SFU. She doesn't really care for the students. She often leaves early and substitutes her lectures with "guest lectuerers". Always on her phones a lot. Very picky yet not helpful at all.
She reads directly from the slides, hence very boring and dry lecture. I would say it is the WORST class I've ever taken at SFU. Complete waste of my money.

I wouldn't take this course again. Lectures are dry and she reads off the slides. Exam questions are all over the place . However, the persona project is engaging and is that about the only fun aspect in the course - unfortunately, it's not worth a significant portion of the final grade. She is also firm about attendance.

Canham is bland and boring lecturer. She reads directly from the powerpoint slides and fails to stimulate any interest into the subject among the students. Other than the attendance marks, there is no reason to attend the lectures. You can just as well read the powerpoint slides afterwards once they are posted online.

Dr. Canham was an overall good professor for GERO 300. The lectures were a bit dry and drawn out, however she provides detailed lecture slide handouts that cover all the material for the tests. She is a bit tough on grading, but it's fair. The textbook is not necessary, apart for one of the paper assignments. There is a semester long group project.
Non-existent throughout the semester and relied heavily on TAs. The course itself was interesting, but disorganized. Not great.

basically non-existent. grades come from 2 essays, a group project, and final. all the lectures are pre-made modules that havent been updated as some of the videos are private. learning the modules is boring to get through so take the class if you want something low maitenence

Atiya was non-existent throughout the semester. It is mainly the TA doing most of the work like responding to emails and marking. If you want to do well in her class, then do the modules. I recommend looking at the textbook to incorporate the ideas for the essays. Make sure that you have everything according to the rubric.
pree much non-existent in the class

Probably THE most unorganized prof i've had. The contents interesting but she makes it so dry. The projects and assignments are kind of unrealistic and tedious and do not help with understanding the course. Her expectations aren't realistic. I just think she's really confused about the whole teaching thing unfortunately.

Lectures were confusing but guest lectures were interesting. Definitely have to attend class to see what's important for the exams which are hard. TA was very nice and helped clarify things for the assignments and exams. Grading was tough but fair, definitely have to study for the exams and start early on assignments. If you do the work its fine.

She's got a great interest in the subject, but she's very confusing and IMO a terrible lecturer - there's basically a guest lecturer every week (to do her part for her!). Her notes are posted online so there's not a huge need to come to class.
